title: 1983–84 UEFA Cup
text:
The 1983–84 UEFA Cup was the 13th season of the <a href="UEFA%20Cup">UEFA Cup</a>, the third-tier club <a href="association%20football">football</a> competition organised by the <a href="UEFA">Union of European Football Associations (UEFA)</a>. It was won by English club <a href="Tottenham%20Hotspur%20F.C.">Tottenham Hotspur</a>, who beat Belgian side <a href="R.S.C.%20Anderlecht">Anderlecht</a> on penalties, after the final finished 2–2 on aggregate.
Association ranking.
For the 1983–84 UEFA Cup, the associations are allocated places according to their 1982 <a href="UEFA%20country%20coefficient">UEFA country coefficient</a>s, which takes into account their performance in European competitions from 1977–78 to 1981–82.
(*) As Albania withdrew.

The labels in the parentheses show how each team qualified for competition:

Second leg.

Quarter-finals.

"Nottingham Forest won 2–1 on aggregate."
"Tottenham Hotspur won 4–2 on aggregate."
"Anderlecht won 4–3 on aggregate."
Semi-finals.
In 1997, it was revealed that the Anderlecht chairman <a href="Constant%20Vanden%20Stock">Constant Vanden Stock</a> had paid a £27,000 bribe to the referee Emilio Guruceta Muro in exchange for help fixing their semi-final second leg match versus Nottingham Forest. During the match, Anderlecht were awarded a dubious <a href="penalty%20kick%20%28association%20football%29">penalty</a>, and a last minute Nottingham Forest goal—that would have won them the tie on the <a href="away%20goals%20rule">away goals rule</a>—was disallowed. In 2016, it emerged that UEFA had known about the bribe since 1993 but had taken no action until the information was made public in 1997, when UEFA suspended Anderlecht from the next European tournament for which they qualified. On qualifying for the <a href="1998%E2%80%9399%20UEFA%20Cup">1998–99 UEFA Cup</a>, Anderlecht appealed the suspension in the <a href="Court%20of%20Arbitration%20for%20Sport">Court of Arbitration for Sport</a>, which overturned the ban on the grounds that it was made by UEFA's executive committee, which did not have the authority to issue the ban.
First leg.
"The match featured an infamous incident that saw a Hajduk fan (later identified as Ante Baraba, a resident of Paljuv settlement within the <a href="Novigrad%2C%20Zadar%20County">Novigrad</a> village) run onto the pitch prior to kickoff with a live <a href="rooster">rooster</a> – in reference to Tottenham's club symbol, the cockerel – and, while standing at the centre circle, proceeding to kill the animal by snapping its neck. The contest took place as scheduled, however, as a result of the incident, Hajduk was fined <a href="Swiss%20franc">CHF</a>3,000 and ordered to play at least 300 km away from their home stadium for their next European tie that turned out to be the <a href="1984%E2%80%9385%20European%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup">1984–85 European Cup Winners' Cup</a> <a href="1984%E2%80%9385%20European%20Cup%20Winners%27%20Cup%23First%20round">first round</a> game against <a href="FC%20Dynamo%20Moscow">Dynamo Moscow</a>."
Second leg.
"Anderlecht won 3–2 on aggregate."
"2–2 on aggregate; Tottenham Hotspur won on away goals."
Final.
Second leg.
"2–2 on aggregate; Tottenham Hotspur won 4–3 on penalties."
